Certainly, it is possible for a story to work without any mention of the protagonist's family relationships. One example of such a story is "The Old Man and the Sea" by Ernest Hemingway.

The novel tells the story of an aging fisherman named Santiago, who is trying to catch a giant marlin in the Gulf Stream off the coast of Cuba. While the novel explores themes of strength, perseverance, and human endurance, Santiago's family relationships are completely absent from the story. There is no mention of his parents, siblings, wife, or children.

Even without any mention of family relationships, "The Old Man and the Sea" is still a powerful and moving story that resonates with readers. The focus on Santiago's individual struggle against nature and his own limitations speaks to universal themes that are relatable to readers of all backgrounds.

In fact, the absence of family relationships in the story can be seen as a deliberate choice on Hemingway's part, as he was known for his minimalist style and focus on individualism. By stripping away any extraneous elements from the story, Hemingway is able to deliver a pure and unvarnished portrait of Santiago's innermost thoughts and emotions.
